column13: The NAB Assist team is the main point of contact for personal and small business customers experiencing financial difficulty. This team will tailor assistance to each customer and their circumstances.

column7: A majority of NAB colleagues supported a new Enterprise Agreement 2024. The Fair Work Commission approved the new Enterprise Agreement 2024 in September 2023 and will commence in February 2024.

column13: NAB's annual ESG materiality assessment is designed to identify and prioritise the ESG areas most relevant to NAB's performance, its stakeholders, and where it can potentially impact society. The outcomes guide reporting and decision-making to help NAB address the ESG topics that matter most.
column20: ESG materiality assessment, stakeholder, decision-making

column7: NAB's material topics are supporting customers, managing climate change, and data security.

column13: NAB's new Accessibility Action Plan 2023 Ã¢ÂÂ 2024 was launched this year, providing a roadmap for improved inclusion and accessibility for customers, colleagues and community members. In 2023, NAB was awarded third place in the Access and Inclusion Index by the Australian Network on Disability.

column13: Farming for the Future is an industry-led program that helps farmers make informed decisions about sustainable long-term management of natural assets to optimise production, build resilience and reduce risks. NAB is providing opportunities for customers to be involved in the program.
column20: Farming for the Future, farmer, natural asset

column13: Detailed credit risk assessment and due diligence are conducted. It includes assessing and identifying material risk issues incorporating ESG risks. ESG-related checklists and guidance notes on various topics and sensitive sectors help guide this activity. It may include assessing a potential customer's background, character, ESG-related performance and the countries in which they operate.

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: NAB's climate strategy is aligned with the Group's strategic ambition to serve customers well and help communities prosper. The appointment of NAB's first Chief Climate Officer, in addition to an increased focus on banker climate training and colleagues' climate capabilities, helps support NAB's whole-of-bank approach to its climate strategy and helps achieve emissions reduction consistent with a maximum temperature rise of 1.5ÃÂ°C above pre-industrial levels by 2100.
column20: Climate strategy, climate training, climate capability

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: In November 2022, NAB launched its Agri Green Loan proposition. This loan helps agribusiness customers invest in eligible on-farm practices and projects such as solar bioenergy, establishing trees, increasing ground cover and crop or pasture diversity, improving soil and water conservation, and building drought resilience.
column20: Agri Green Loan, agribusiness, solar bioenergy

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: NAB's business finance for green equipment can support on-farm emission reductions. It includes energy-efficient tractors, best-in-class combine, cotton and sugar cane harvesters, and energy-efficient irrigation. This product can support customers seeking to manage nature-related impacts, such as GHG emissions.
column20: Business finance for green equipment, on-farm emission reduction, nature-related impact

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: In 2023, NAB launched its carbon markets capability, providing risk management solutions across domestic and international markets to support customers' carbon and renewable energy needs. Products include Australian Carbon Credit Units (ACCU), Large Scale Generation Certificates (LGC) and European Union Allowances (EUA). It follows the development of Carbonplace, a carbon credit settlement platform jointly developed by NAB and some of the world's largest financial institutions.
column20: Carbon market, risk management solution, renewable energy

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column8: Green, social, sustainability and sustainability-linked (GSSS) bonds
column13: NAB has been an Australian market leader in green, social, sustainability and sustainability-linked (GSSS) bond issuance since becoming the first Australian bank issuer of a Certified green bond under the Climate Bond Standard (CBS) in 2014. NAB green bonds allow investors to direct capital towards projects and assets that may contribute towards the objectives of the Paris Agreement or address environmental challenges.
column20: GSSS Bond, Climate Bond Standard, green bond

column6: Defined benefit plan obligations and other retirement plans
column7: In 2023, the Group renegotiated the new EA by undertaking extensive negotiations and colleague engagement. The new EA provides certainty about pay and additional benefits to eligible colleagues, including an annual one-week You Leave.

column13: NAB and Good Shepherd Australia New Zealand have worked together since 2003 to help Australians manage their money better and serve those at risk of exclusion from mainstream banking services. The partnership began through NAB's support of microfinance initiatives aiming to support low-income people Ã¢ÂÂ mainly the No Interest Loans (NILs) program. It is one of NAB's longest-standing corporate community partnerships.
column20: Good Shepherd, microfinance, low-income people

column13: NAB works closely with the Federal Government's major housing financing body, Housing Australia, to help create the right financing conditions to build scale in social and affordable housing aligned with the Federal Government's ambition for 40,000 social and affordable homes by 2029. This year, NAB helped to finance social, affordable and community housing transactions, which included build-to-rent, land lease and mixed tenure models. NAB is focused on connecting and influencing key stakeholders through networks in the affordable housing sector and working closely with community partners like Good Shepherd and the Salvation Army.
column20: Housing Australia, financing condition, community housing

column13: Life with a disability can make finding a liveable home harder. In 2023, NAB financed the construction of some significant specialist homes for people living with a disability. It included finance to the Australian Disability Accommodation Projects. NAB is working with Lighthouse Infrastructure and a consortium of lenders to carry out its largest commitment in the SDA sector and the first social loan for SDA in Australia.
column20: Australian Disability Accommodation Project, home, Lighthouse Infrastructure

column13: NAB is helping people earning incomes under the national median access homeownership as part of the First Home Guarantee (FHG) scheme, which has established income and other eligibility criteria. NAB's affordable and specialist housing target includes a subset of loans provided via the FHG for loans where applicants have a total taxable income under the national median and for properties with a price under the national median. NAB is a founding bank in this scheme and, in 2023, has financed loans in this subset of housing, approximately 5,127 borrowers.
column20: First Home Guarantee, loan, specialist housing target

column13: NAB's BNZ supports New Zealanders in warm, dry and resilient homes. The focus has been on shared ownership models that support construction and new home ownership. One of these initiatives is First Home Partner, a shared ownership initiative with KÃÂinga Ora aimed at helping people who have a household income of under NZD 150,000 and a minimum of 5% deposit.
column20: First Home Partner, shared ownership model, household income

column13: NAB is working on solutions that address cost of living pressures and benefit customers who manage their climate impact. Lower variable rates and discounted Lenders Mortgage Insurance were launched in October 2022 to eligible home loan customers on homes that meet energy efficiency criteria. With Australian homes contributing more than 10% of Australia's total emissions, this initiative aims to support customers in reducing their emissions.
column20: Lenders Mortgage Insurance, cost of living, energy efficiency

column13: NAB continues to support the Bushfire Resilience Rating system, which aims to help households adapt their homes to make them more resilient to bushfires. In 2023, NAB supported the Bushfire Resilience Ratings Retrofit Pilot in bushfire-impacted New South Wales and Victoria areas. NAB offers discounted lending to participating households investing in their property's resilience.
column20: Bushfire Resilience Rating, household, bushfire

column13: NAB's Ready Together program supported customers impacted by natural disasters with $557,000 in cash grants during the year. The grant application process has also been made easier with a new online application form for customers to apply for an emergency relief grant.
column20: Ready Together program, natural disaster, emergency relief

column6: Operations assessed for risks related to corruption
column13: The past 18 months of sanctions, export, and import controls have been unprecedented in scope, complexity, and impact. Enforcement by global sanctions regulators remains significant, with USD 1 billion in penalties issued globally in the financial year 2023. To ensure compliance, NAB has continued to improve its Sanctions Compliance Program, including implementing a new trade screening program and enhancing its controls for identifying and monitoring high sanctions risk customers.
column20: Sanctions Compliance Program, sanctions regulator, trade screening

column6: Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
column13: NAB continues executing the financial crime strategy launched in 2022. While NAB is making good progress, the nature of the threat and risk it presents requires ongoing vigilance and pursuit of best practices in all that NAB does.
column20: Financial crime strategy, threat, vigilance

column6: Confirmed incidents of corruption and actions taken
column13: The Group is committed to preventing financial crime and takes a zero-tolerance approach to bribery and corruption. It is reflected in the Group's Anti-Bribery and Corruption (ABC) Policy and Framework. The prohibition against bribery and corruption in the ABC Policy applies to NAB's entities, colleagues and all agents, contractors and other third parties acting for or on behalf of the Group. The Group strictly prohibits bribery in any form (including facilitation payments). The ABC Policy includes additional requirements around gifts and entertainment involving government officials, which require approvals regardless of value.
column20: Anti-Bribery and Corruption Policy, financial crime, gift

column6: Legal actions for anti-competitive behavior, anti-trust, and monopoly practices
column7: As a global finance and trade bank, the Group faces risks relating to compliance with AML/CTF, ABC and financial sanctions laws across multiple jurisdictions. Undetected failure of internal controls or the ineffective remediation of compliance issues could lead to breaches of AML/CTF and ABC obligations or sanctions violations, resulting in potentially significant monetary and regulatory penalties, which, in turn, may adversely impact the Group's reputation, financial performance, and position.
The NAB Board is responsible for determining the NAB's Tax Policy and the approach to tax risk governance.

column6: Tax governance, control, and risk management
column13: NAB maintains a robust tax control framework, subject to regular testing and assurance. Tax risk is managed in the context of the Group's framework on risk management accountabilities. NAB exercises strong governance over its tax affairs. NAB maintains and enforces strict protocols to control the type of transactions that NAB enters into and the associated tax risks.
column20: Tax control framework, tax risk, tax affair
